text: Thanks for taking the time to hear me.  I'm on a totally different subject again, it's been quite a diverse range of submitters this morning. I'm here to talk about cats, as you know from my submission. I'd like to just start by giving you a picture of my experience with animals bylaws. Just last year alone, I submitted on every single animals bylaw notified in the North Island, and I assisted with two in the South Island.  So, I feel like I have a pretty good grasp of what's going on, particularly in the North Island regarding these bylaws. And I tried to get clarification, but I haven't had a reply from Council yet. But I understand that Waipā  did not run any form of survey of the community ahead of this process, nor did I get the impression it consulted any focus groups. Certainly that wasn't stated in the statement of proposal. And so in my experience, most councils do run some kind of pre-consultation because then they draft a bylaw that's most appropriate to the district. And maybe the concerns around bees is testament to that.  In my experience, every council that surveys the community ahead of notifying its animals bylaw has cats raised as a topic of concern from stray cat colonies, people illegally dumping in public reserves, nuisance cats defecating in sand pits, tomcats fighting at night, et cetera. The list is endless. Cat nuisance is a genuine concern across New Zealand and simply having a generic nuisance clause in your bylaw  doesn't go far enough to truly address the issue. I do contend that your officer's claim is incorrect, that this bylaw can't include rules for cats. They've stated that because this bylaw is based upon transferring into bylaw form some existing district plan rules regarding animals in urban areas, that these rules do not include cats. So therefore it's not possible to include the rules in this bylaw,  I would suggest that that's a red herring because in the context of this bylaw, it's been issued under the Local Government Act and not the RMA. So WIPA has every ability to introduce rules specific to cats in this bylaw, as demonstrated by many other councils who have done exactly that. In fact, WIPA's enforcement officers need stronger regulation so that when a nuisance occurs,  they have the power to actually reduce the nuisance. When cats aren't microchipped, for example, the officers won't have any way of knowing who owns the nuisance cats, thereby making their ability to abate the nuisance even more difficult. Similarly, research has indicated that return to owner rates of cats that are microchipped is 20 times higher than for cats that are not. I'd like to point out that cat regulation is not a big deal.  Not only is it desired by the community, it's also well-supported. Just to give you an example, in Taupo District last year, the council proposed nuisance regulation after hearing the concerns of its residents. Not only did 92% of submitters support the proposed regulation, many called on the council to do more in a similar vein to what Forest and Bird has proposed in its by-law submission to WIPA, such as compulsory microchipping, de-sexing, and a three-cat limit.  In Whangarei, a district that has a cat problem, in their statement of proposal, they made it clear they weren't proposing specific regulation, but kept the door open to submitters who may have had a view. Their statement of proposal invited community views on matters relating to keeping of cats and feedback on the possible options for cat management. And Whangarei District Council wasn't proposing changes relating to cats in its amended bylaw, but options were considered as part of the bylaw review.  some sort of by-law regulation was within the scope of the consultation, I suggest the process run by WIPA has done a disservice to WIPA residents. By only consulting on a narrow scope, residents weren't really even aware that animals by-laws are in fact absolutely an appropriate place to regulate cats, that many councils are regulating cats through their animals by-laws and that strict regulation is being passed in other districts and no one is batting an eyelid. In 2020,  Whanganui District Council passed the strictest cat regulation in the country and even Companion Animals New Zealand was completely in support. You'll find that forest and bird and the animal protection groups are actually all on the same page. We all want the best outcomes for the cats. We just want them to be managed such that their impact on our wildlife is minimized. So we implore you to include stricter cat regulation in this bylaw and not fall behind those councils showing genuine leadership in this space. That's all I had to say.  Thank you.
